creditline: Gift of funds from Mary and Bob Mersky and gift of Gayle Rodda Kurtz in memory of William Olander
description: brightly colored, highly textured painting depicting several different vignettes in the four quadrants; ULQ: figure with spots, releasing bird on outstretched arm, another figure nearby; birds with figures against red and orange sky; two dogs looking out from either side of brick wall; URQ: birds and clouds against red sky; line of figures, rabbits, birds along sky; dog and bird in black silhouette; C: cartouche against textured red background with duck and the head of a figure bobbing in water; LLQ: figure in hat, and another in striped shirt against spotted sky, with another figure and bird in orange; silhouetted figures against red in lower C; LRQ: figures and birds looking to R edge with lines of spots; figure at R edge with bird; turtle or bird figure with two heads and wings near LRC
signed: on back, in paint: Roy De Forest | A Bird in Hand | Polymer Paint
text: Roy De Forest loved dogs and he had a disarming sense of humor. He loved nature and being in the landscape, and he loved puns and wordplay. All of this is evident in a raucous, vibrant scene in which geography shifts scale abruptly in several places, moving from a “bird’s-eye view” one moment, to a close up look in another. De Forest developed a personal style that was unlike anyone else’s – kinetically colorful and full of lively details. And always, dogs!
title: A Bird in Hand
